qas.question: What is one type of circuit in which voltage and current reversal are affected by damping?
What is another type of circuit in which voltage and current reversal are affected by damping?
Under what condition does voltage reversal occur in RLC circuits?
What is formed between the inductance and the capacitance when the current and the voltage switch direction?
When a system is over-damped, what does it typically not experience?

context: In <a0_0>DC circuits<a0_0/> and <a1_0>pulsed circuits<a1_0/>, current and voltage reversal are affected by the damping of the system. Voltage reversal is encountered in RLC circuits that are <a2_0>under-damped<a2_0/>. The current and voltage reverse direction, forming <a3_0>a harmonic oscillator<a3_0/> between the inductance and capacitance. The current and voltage will tend to oscillate and may reverse direction several times, with each peak being lower than the previous, until the system reaches an equilibrium. This is often referred to as ringing. In comparison, critically damped or over-damped systems usually do not experience <a4_0>a voltage reversal<a4_0/>. Reversal is also encountered in AC circuits, where the peak current will be equal in each direction.
